label: Continuous Feedback & Recognition
description: Weekly/biweekly check-ins with AI-prompted feedback, real-time peer recognition, and sentiment analysis replacing annual reviews with continuous performance conversations driving 25% employee satisfaction improvement.

traditional.workflow: 1. Manager provides performance feedback once per year during annual review (60-90 minute meeting). 2. Feedback suffers from recency bias (entire year judged on last 2-3 months). 3. Employee surprised by feedback (no ongoing conversations throughout year). 4. Manager writes review in isolation, submits to HR for processing. 5. Recognition ad-hoc and infrequent (maybe quarterly awards for top performers). 6. 2.5/5 employee satisfaction with performance management (reviews dreaded, seen as punitive).
constraints: Annual feedback creates 364 days of blindness (no ongoing conversations)
Recency bias makes reviews unfair (ignores 10 months of performance)
Surprises and defensiveness from lack of continuous dialogue
Recognition infrequent and inconsistent (quarterly awards only)
Low employee satisfaction (2.5/5) - reviews seen as negative experience
No real-time course correction when performance issues arise

agentic.workflow: 1. Continuous Feedback & Recognition Agent sends weekly check-in prompts via Slack/Teams: 'How's John doing on the customer portal project? Any feedback to share?'. 2. Manager provides quick feedback in 2-3 minutes: 'Great progress on API design, customer happy. Work on communication - keep project stakeholders updated proactively'. 3. Agent aggregates feedback over time, tracks themes and patterns: 'John receiving consistent praise for technical skills, opportunity areas in communication and stakeholder management'. 4. Agent enables peer-to-peer recognition: 'Give John a kudos for helping you debug the authentication issue - visible to team and management'. 5. Agent analyzes feedback sentiment: detects positive trends (morale improving), negative trends (engagement dropping), or concerning patterns (conflict with peer). 6. Agent surfaces feedback history during quarterly development discussions: manager reviews 12 weeks of continuous feedback with John, no surprises or recency bias.
dataSources: Weekly/biweekly check-in feedback from managers
Peer-to-peer recognition and kudos data
Project collaboration and contribution data
Sentiment analysis of feedback tone and patterns
Feedback themes and categorization (strengths, opportunities)
Historical feedback trends over time
benefits: 25% improvement in employee satisfaction (4.0/5 vs 2.5/5) through continuous dialogue
Recency bias eliminated by reviewing 52 weeks of feedback vs last 2-3 months
No surprises - employees know strengths and opportunities in real-time
Real-time course correction when issues arise (vs waiting for annual review)
Frequent recognition (weekly peer kudos) vs quarterly awards only
Manager burden spread throughout year (2-3 min weekly) vs 60-90 min annual marathon

quickWins: Deploy weekly check-in prompts via Slack/Teams for pilot teams
Enable peer recognition platform with visible kudos
Implement manager feedback aggregation dashboard to review themes
prerequisites: Performance management platform with continuous feedback capability
Slack/Teams integration for feedback prompts
Recognition platform or capability (built-in or standalone)
Manager training on effective feedback delivery
Cultural shift from annual to continuous mindset (executive sponsorship)

label: Goal Setting & Tracking (OKRs/MBOs)
description: Quarterly OKR cascading with real-time progress tracking, red/yellow/green status alerts, and strategic alignment visualization achieving 85-90% goal completion versus 60-70% annual static goals.

traditional.workflow: 1. Manager sets employee goals during annual review (3-5 goals for the year). 2. Goals written in Word document or performance management system, rarely revisited. 3. No goal progress tracking or check-ins mid-year (set-and-forget). 4. Manager remembers goals 12 months later during next annual review (or forgets). 5. Employee achieves 60-70% of goals on average (if goals even remembered or still relevant). 6. No cascading from company strategy (employee goals disconnected from organizational objectives).
constraints: Annual goals static and inflexible (business priorities change quarterly)
No progress tracking or mid-year check-ins (set-and-forget)
60-70% goal completion rate due to lack of accountability and alignment
Goals disconnected from company strategy (no cascading alignment)
12-month time horizon too long (priorities shift, goals become irrelevant)
No visibility into team's goals (siloed individual goal setting)

agentic.workflow: 1. Goal Setting & Tracking Agent cascades company OKRs down organization: company objective 'Expand enterprise market share' → department objective 'Close 50 enterprise deals' → individual objective 'Generate 200 qualified enterprise leads'. 2. Agent helps employee set quarterly OKRs with SMART criteria and measurable key results: 'Generate 200 qualified enterprise leads (current: 50/quarter)'. 3. Agent tracks progress in real-time: integrates with CRM, project management tools, business systems to auto-update OKR completion (e.g., 120/200 leads = 60% progress, yellow status). 4. Agent provides weekly progress check-ins: 'You're 60% toward lead generation goal with 8 weeks remaining (on track). Sarah on your team at 30% (at risk) - offer support?'. 5. Agent enables goal adjustments mid-quarter: business priority shifts, manager and employee revise OKR with approval workflow. 6. Agent visualizes organizational alignment: shows how individual OKRs ladder up to department and company objectives (transparency and purpose).
dataSources: Company, department, and team OKRs for cascading
Individual employee OKRs and key results
CRM, project management, and business system data for progress tracking
Weekly/monthly progress updates and status (red/yellow/green)
Goal revision history and approval workflows
Organizational hierarchy for alignment visualization
benefits: 85-90% goal completion rate (vs 60-70%) through accountability and tracking
Quarterly OKR cycle aligns with business agility vs inflexible annual goals
Real-time progress tracking (red/yellow/green status) vs annual review surprise
Strategic alignment transparency shows how individual work contributes to company goals
Mid-quarter goal adjustment capability adapts to changing business priorities
Manager visibility into team's goal progress enables proactive coaching

quickWins: Deploy quarterly OKR framework for pilot departments
Implement real-time progress tracking from CRM and project management systems
Enable OKR alignment visualization showing cascade from company to individual
prerequisites: OKR methodology training for managers and employees
Performance management platform with OKR capability
Integration with business systems for progress tracking (CRM, project management)
Company and department OKRs defined and communicated
Cultural shift from annual to quarterly goal cycles (executive sponsorship)

label: 360 Feedback Orchestration
description: AI-recommended rater selection with automated survey distribution, intelligent reminders, and response rate optimization achieving 75-85% response rates versus 40-60% manual email-based 360 processes.

traditional.workflow: 1. Employee nominates 5-8 peers, subordinates, stakeholders for 360 feedback during annual review. 2. Manager reviews and approves nominations (may add or remove raters). 3. HR manually sends 360 survey emails to nominated raters (often weeks after review cycle starts). 4. 40-60% response rate after 2-3 manual reminder emails over 4-6 weeks. 5. HR manually consolidates responses in Excel, anonymizes feedback (redacting names from comments). 6. 360 report shared with employee and manager 6-8 weeks after initial nomination (too late for timely action).
constraints: Manual rater nomination and approval (employee may nominate friends, avoid critics)
40-60% response rate due to email-based reminders and survey fatigue
6-8 week 360 cycle from nomination to report delivery (too slow)
Manual anonymization and consolidation takes HR 2-4 hours per employee
No intelligent rater selection (quality of feedback depends on nominee choices)
360 only during annual review (infrequent, high-stakes)

agentic.workflow: 1. 360 Feedback Orchestration Agent recommends raters based on collaboration data: 'You've worked with Sarah on 3 projects, exchanged 50+ emails, attended 10 meetings - strong candidate for peer feedback'. 2. Agent balances rater mix: ensures diverse perspectives (peers, manager, subordinates, cross-functional stakeholders) and avoids bias (not all friends or allies). 3. Agent sends survey invitations with personalized messages: 'John has requested your feedback as part of his development - your insights are valuable and will remain confidential'. 4. Agent sends intelligent reminders: friendly 1-week reminder, urgent 3-day reminder with time estimate ('10 minutes to complete'), final push 24 hours before deadline with SMS/Slack escalation. 5. Agent achieves 75-85% response rate through multi-channel reminders and nudges. 6. Agent auto-consolidates responses, anonymizes feedback, generates 360 report in 2-3 weeks vs 6-8 weeks manual.
dataSources: Employee collaboration data (projects, emails, meetings, Slack/Teams interactions)
Organizational hierarchy and reporting relationships
Historical 360 participation and response quality data
Survey response tracking and reminder history
Rater feedback quality and calibration data
360 survey templates and question libraries
benefits: 75-85% response rate (vs 40-60%) through intelligent reminders and multi-channel nudges
20-30 point response rate improvement drives higher quality 360 feedback
AI rater selection ensures diverse perspectives and reduces bias
2-3 week cycle time (vs 6-8 weeks) provides timely feedback for action
Automated consolidation and anonymization saves HR 2-4 hours per employee
Quarterly 360 capability vs annual only (continuous development focus)

quickWins: Deploy AI rater recommendations based on collaboration data for pilot group
Implement multi-channel reminder sequence (email + SMS + Slack)
Enable automated 360 report generation with anonymization
prerequisites: 360 survey platform with automation capability
Collaboration data from email, calendar, project management systems
Multi-channel notification infrastructure (email, SMS, Slack)
Survey templates and question libraries
Anonymization and reporting automation
Manager training on delivering 360 feedback

label: Performance Analytics & Insights
description: Predictive performance analytics with flight risk correlation, high performer identification, succession readiness scoring, and performance trend analysis enabling data-driven talent decisions and 20-40% attrition reduction.

traditional.workflow: 1. HR compiles annual performance ratings in Excel spreadsheet (3-5 rating categories). 2. HR calculates performance distribution: 10% top performers, 70% meets expectations, 20% below expectations. 3. HR creates PowerPoint presentation showing performance by department for leadership review. 4. No predictive analytics or flight risk correlation (high performers leave without warning). 5. Succession planning ad-hoc based on manager opinions (no data-driven readiness scores). 6. Performance trends not analyzed (is this employee improving, declining, plateauing?).
constraints: Performance ratings backward-looking only (no predictive analytics)
High performers leave without warning (no flight risk correlation)
Succession planning based on manager gut feel (no readiness scoring)
Performance distribution reported but not actionable (so what?)
No trend analysis (improving vs declining performance over time)
Talent decisions reactive (respond to resignations) vs proactive (retain before they leave)

agentic.workflow: 1. Performance Analytics & Insights Agent analyzes performance data to identify high performers: consistent top ratings, strong 360 feedback, goal overachievement, positive continuous feedback. 2. Agent correlates performance with flight risk: 'High performers with stagnant salary growth 40% more likely to leave within 6 months' or 'Top performers with no promotion in 3+ years at elevated attrition risk'. 3. Agent calculates succession readiness scores: 'Sarah ready for Director role (85% readiness: strong performance, leadership skills, lacks cross-functional experience)'. 4. Agent tracks performance trends: 'John's performance declining over last 3 quarters (4.5 → 4.0 → 3.5) - recommend manager intervention'. 5. Agent identifies engagement patterns: 'High performers in Engineering giving 30% less continuous feedback - potential morale issue, investigate'. 6. Agent provides talent insights dashboard: top performers by team, flight risk alerts, succession pipeline, performance trends for data-driven talent decisions.
dataSources: Performance ratings history and trends over time
Continuous feedback volume and sentiment
360 feedback results and peer ratings
Goal achievement and OKR completion rates
Compensation history (salary, bonus, promotion timing)
Engagement survey responses and sentiment
Attrition history and exit interview themes
Skills and competency assessment data
benefits: 20-40% attrition reduction through proactive flight risk intervention
Data-driven succession planning with readiness scores vs manager opinions
High performer retention through targeted compensation and development interventions
Performance trend analysis enables early intervention before ratings decline
Engagement pattern detection surfaces team morale issues for investigation
Talent decisions shift from reactive (resignation response) to proactive (retention before departure)
metrics: High performer identification: Multi-factor (ratings + feedback + goals)

quickWins: Deploy high performer identification algorithm combining ratings, feedback, goals
Implement flight risk model correlating performance with compensation and tenure
Create succession readiness scoring for top 50 critical roles
prerequisites: Performance management data (minimum 2-3 years history)
Compensation and promotion data from HRIS
Continuous feedback and 360 data for multi-factor analysis
Attrition history and exit interview themes for flight risk model training
Analytics platform or data warehouse for predictive modeling
Machine learning capability for flight risk and succession models
Executive sponsorship for data-driven talent decisions

label: Development & Career Planning
description: Personalized development plans based on performance feedback themes, skills gaps, and career aspirations with recommended experiences, training, and stretch assignments driving 40-60% faster skill development.

traditional.workflow: 1. Manager provides generic development feedback during annual review: 'Work on leadership skills and communication'. 2. Employee expected to create own development plan (most don't know how). 3. 30% of employees create development plans, 70% do nothing. 4. Development plans generic: 'Read leadership books, attend communication workshop' with no specific actions or timeline. 5. No follow-up or accountability on development plan execution. 6. Next annual review, manager and employee forget about development plan (no progress made).
constraints: Generic development feedback ('improve leadership') with no actionable guidance
70% of employees don't create development plans (lack clarity and resources)
30% who create plans don't execute (no accountability or follow-up)
Development disconnected from career goals (what am I developing for?)
No recommended experiences, training, or stretch assignments (employee must figure out)
Annual review cycle too infrequent for effective development (need continuous coaching)

agentic.workflow: 1. Development & Career Planning Agent analyzes performance feedback themes from continuous check-ins and 360: 'Sarah receiving consistent feedback to improve stakeholder communication and strategic thinking'. 2. Agent identifies skills gaps from competency model: 'Sarah's current role requires advanced stakeholder management (she's at intermediate) and strategic planning (she's at basic)'. 3. Agent considers career aspirations: 'Sarah wants to move into Product Management which requires customer empathy and roadmap planning skills'. 4. Agent tracks development progress: 'Sarah completed course, shadowing PM week 2 of 4, cross-functional project on track'. 6. Agent provides quarterly check-ins: 'How is stakeholder management going? What support needed for cross-functional project leadership?'.

label: Calibration & Compensation Alignment
description: AI-assisted performance calibration across managers with anomaly detection, pay equity analysis, and pay-for-performance modeling achieving 70-85% time savings and ensuring fair compensation decisions.

traditional.workflow: 1. Managers submit performance ratings for their teams to HR (no cross-manager discussion). 2. HR schedules 8-12 hour calibration session with all department managers in conference room. 3. Managers debate ratings case-by-case: 'Why is Sarah rated 4.5 while Bob is 4.0 with similar accomplishments?'. 4. Forced distribution applied: 10% top performers, 70% meets expectations, 20% needs improvement (creates unhealthy competition). 5. Compensation decisions made after calibration in separate process (ratings → merit budget allocation in spreadsheet). 6. No systematic pay equity analysis (gender, race, tenure pay gaps undiscovered).
constraints: 8-12 hour calibration sessions drain manager time and productivity
Forced distribution creates artificial scarcity and unhealthy competition
Ratings subjective and inconsistent across managers (lenient vs tough raters)
Compensation decisions disconnected from performance calibration (separate process)
No pay equity analysis (demographic pay gaps, tenure compression undiscovered)
Manual compensation planning in spreadsheets error-prone and time-consuming

agentic.workflow: 1. Calibration Agent pre-analyzes ratings before calibration session: identifies outliers (manager rating all employees 4.5+), inconsistencies (similar employees rated differently), and forced distribution impacts. 2. Agent provides data-driven calibration recommendations: 'Sarah and Bob have similar goal achievement (90% vs 88%) and 360 scores (4.3 vs 4.2) - recommend both rated 4.5 vs Sarah 4.5 and Bob 4.0'. 3. Agent reduces calibration meeting to 2-3 hours (vs 8-12 hours) by pre-flagging only cases needing discussion (20-30% of employees). 4. Agent performs pay equity analysis: 'Women in Engineering rated 4.2 avg receiving 3.0% merit vs men rated 4.2 receiving 3.5% merit - investigate pay disparity'. 5. Agent models pay-for-performance scenarios: 'Current merit budget of 3.5% applied to ratings yields 2.5% merit for meets expectations, 4.5% for exceeds - does this align with philosophy?'. 6. Agent flags compensation anomalies: 'John rated top performer but paid at market 50th percentile - retention risk, recommend adjustment'.
dataSources: Manager-submitted performance ratings and justifications
Goal achievement, 360 feedback, continuous feedback data
Employee compensation history and current salary
Market compensation benchmarks by role and location
Pay equity data (gender, race, tenure, demographics)
Merit budget and compensation philosophy guidelines
Historical calibration decisions and rating distributions
benefits: 70-85% time savings (2-3 hours vs 8-12 hours) through AI pre-analysis
Rating consistency improved through data-driven recommendations
Pay equity analysis ensures fair compensation across demographics
Pay-for-performance modeling aligns merit increases with ratings philosophy
Anomaly detection identifies retention risks (high performers underpaid)
Manager satisfaction improved (less time, more fair outcomes)
